div1.p: Carter provides family news and describes Christmas celebrations.

div1.head: Letter from Henry Rose Carter to Emma Coleman Carter, December 17, 1883
div1.opener:
what to give a china-boy
He is of quite good family- son of a teacher & can
write, sends all of his money to his mother
& writes home every month - 7 years learning to
write.
Dec 17/83
Dear Ma:
div1.p:
You will get this Xmas day
I think or just before. Well we, please
God, will have a better Xmas than
last year & I would tell you all about it
only I doubt if I have time.

May left last Monday to teach at San
Rafael -(pronounced, Rafell) about 3/4 to
1 hours ride from San Francisco. She wrote
to us Saturday, 3 scholars, &c But I will
not tell you aught of her because she
doubtless wrote yesterday to you herself.
I think it is a good place & not a bad
salary. She will be much happier in-
deed it will be a good thing for her
to feel independent -tho' she need
never have felt otherwise - & for her to
go among people a little more. Her
health is again good, she has not had as
happypleasant a time as I had hoped her
to have with us. Although she says
she has enjoyed herself more than
since her childhood. I doubt that however.
Chas may came & may not, if he can get
a cheap ticket, yes; if not, no. $40 is the price of
the return ticket & that is a good deal.
He wants to come poor fellow & I would
wish well to see him, & hope he can come.
He is more contented & is not taking things
so hard. He will need more money about
Jan 1st & I have made arrangements to
let him have $75 or $100. He doesn't seem
to have gotten into business as fast as I
had hoped & yet I really had no data
to base an opinion on.

I have had charge of Ned one day i.e. from
1. to 5. P. M. Wednesday. L. Annie & Dedie
went in town to get some things, it being
Dedie's birth-day. Well, Ed & I fought it out
on that line. Only once I rebelled when he
wanted to ride, “horsey-back.” I can't hold him
& ride him too. He can walk but won't. The
most reckless child I ever saw. L.' being a little
sick yesterday I took him last night & we
got through very well. I begin to consider
myself quite a baby nurse. He is rather
too fond of me for comfort, but not for compli
ment.

After consideration we have decided that
little L.' is big enough to appreciate Xmas.
So,- following L.' Dutch traditions - we will have
a small Xmas tree, (35 cents) & fix it up, every
thing about $2 20/100, not much candy, but pretty
things. She is very fond of them & very obser-
vant, L. has baked a lot of "cookies" etc
We won't have any Xmas dinner, it is
more worry to the women folks: & Coon
than it is worth to methose who cares as
little about eating as we do. If
Chas does not come we will send
him a box, for he likes good things
May will be home-with us I mean-
Friday.

Our china-boy, Ah Coon - (Ah=Mr.),
is our despair, he has made about 100
small presents - mainly utterly uneatable
Chinese eatables- Perserved fruit put up in
salt. Fish in Oil of Sandal-wood. Perser-
ved Bamboo-root, which is certainly eco-
nomical. 4 stout men can eat a piece
an inch cube for 6 hours & not ex-
haust it. Some things. (Ginger & L Chee
Li Chee nuts) are quite good, He
brought L.' a nest of painted boxes. & last sun-
day, brought Ed a bird (not a real bird) in
a squeaking cage & L.' 2 vases which, if
not smuggled, must have cost 3 or 4 dollars.
The squeak of the cage scared Ed - he gets in-
to a perfect panic' sometimes. Yesterday
he bought 4 fancy cake cutters, & a box of tea
16 lbs (box & all), for which we paid $4.00
better tea than we had paid 75 cents a
lb. for. He got the tea underorder, but
the other things weigh on us, The obliga-
tion of them I mean. One does not know
Don't we live differently from what we
did Mother, I missed the pleasantest life
for me though when I left the country
& farming. I doubt if I ever be able to live
on a farm again, but it is, for me, beyond
all comparison the best life.

We are better off than last Xmas, thank God,
L, then was weak & I was anxious about her.
She is getting in good health now & spite
of some setbacks is slowly getting stronger.
I hardly thought Dedie would live then,
now she is as strong & tough as one could
well see a child, & Ed is big & strong too
Chas, I hope, is where he will do well.
May is probably doing better than she
could have done in Va. & I see no reason,
if she doesn't worry any more & take exercise, why she
should not stay in good health,
I feel that I we have much to be thank-
ful for & it may even turn out to be
an advantage that I came to this coast.
We have been having quite cold weather
7° below freezing - & yet we have geranium
Hearts ease & violets & heliotrope in
bloom, although slightly nipped.
Can't say a great deal for the cli-
mate however.

The Yellow Fever patients are let
out into the general ward this mor-
ning.

The $10. was sent for Mary or as you think
L. made D. a Mother Hubbard dress
about $1.40, & the nurse said that a dozen
ladies stopped her in town to talk to
her. She is very pretty & bright looking &
doubtless the dress became her.

I can send Nan a little money every month,
if you think so.

All send love to Gran & Aunt Empsy
& to the Cousins, especially Kate

Did the children get the St. Nicholas
for which May subscribed for them?
div1.closer: Your affec'ate Son Henry R. Carter,
